name: Bunyakovsky conjecture
rephrased: A certain type of polynomial (one that is irreducible, has positive leading coefficient, and doesn't share a common factor greater than 1 with all its integer outputs) will always produce an infinite number of prime numbers when evaluated at positive integers.
implication_form: If a non-constant polynomial with integer coefficients is irreducible over the integers, has a positive leading coefficient, and the values it takes at positive integers have no common prime divisor, then it takes on infinitely many prime values.
explained: The Bunyakovsky conjecture is a hypothesis in number theory proposing that a non-constant polynomial with integer coefficients will produce infinitely many prime numbers if it satisfies three conditions: its leading coefficient is positive, it is irreducible over the integers (cannot be factored into non-constant polynomials with integer coefficients), and the greatest common divisor of all its integer values is 1.
